definitions: mark or cover something with ink for writing or printing
sign or formally agree to a contract or document
examples: The artist carefully inked the drawing before scanning it
She inked each letter with precision using her fountain pen
They finally inked the deal after months of negotiations
The player inked a five-year contract with the team

definitions: set pieces of material into a surface to form a decorative pattern
insert material into something to fill gaps or create designs
examples: The craftsman inlaid mother-of-pearl into the wooden jewelry box
They inlaid gold strips into the marble floor design
The dentist will inlay a filling into the prepared tooth cavity
Workers inlaid new tiles where the old ones had cracked

definitions: develop new ideas, methods, or products through creative thinking
make changes in something established by introducing new methods or ideas
examples: The company continues to innovate in the field of renewable energy
Scientists innovate constantly to solve complex medical problems
We need to innovate our teaching methods for online learning
The restaurant innovated its menu to attract younger customers

definitions: enter data or information into a computer or other electronic device
provide ideas, suggestions, or contributions to a discussion or project
examples: Please input your password to access the secure database
She input all the sales figures into the spreadsheet
We need everyone to input their thoughts during the brainstorming session
The consultant will input her expertise into the project

definitions: ask for information from someone about something specific
conduct a formal investigation or make official queries about something
examples: She inquired about the availability of rooms at the hotel
Many customers inquire about our return policy before purchasing
The committee will inquire into the cause of the accident
Police inquired into his whereabouts on the night of the robbery

definitions: place, fit, or push something into something else carefully
add text or other material into a document or publication
examples: Insert the key into the lock and turn it clockwise
The surgeon will insert a small tube into the patient's artery
Please insert a comma between these two independent clauses
The editor decided to insert a footnote explaining the reference

definitions: fix something firmly into a surface or place it within something else
examples: The jeweler will inset diamonds into the platinum band
They inset decorative tiles into the bathroom wall design

definitions: demand something forcefully and refuse to accept refusal or opposition
state or maintain a position or claim firmly despite opposition
examples: She insisted that everyone arrive on time for the meeting
The manager insisted on checking every detail before approval
He still insists that he saw a UFO that night
Despite the evidence, she insists on her innocence

definitions: look at something or someone carefully to discover information or check quality
officially examine something to ensure it meets required standards or regulations
examples: The mechanic will inspect your car's brakes before the trip
She inspected the fabric closely for any signs of damage
Health officials inspect restaurants regularly for safety compliance
The building inspector will inspect the property next Tuesday

definitions: fill someone with the urge or ability to do or feel something creative
cause someone to have a particular feeling or reaction
breathe in air or other substances into the lungs
examples: Her courage inspired him to pursue his dreams despite obstacles
The beautiful landscape inspired the artist to paint masterpieces
The speech inspired confidence in the team before the championship
His kindness inspired gratitude in everyone he helped
The patient was instructed to inspire deeply during the lung examination
Swimmers must inspire quickly between strokes

definitions: put equipment or machinery in position ready for use
place someone in a new position of authority or importance
establish someone or something in a new place or role formally
examples: The technician will install the new software on your computer
They installed solar panels on the roof last summer
The board will install the new CEO at next week's ceremony
The university installed her as department chair yesterday
The museum installed the new exhibition in the main gallery
They installed themselves in the corner office

definitions: mention something as an example or to support an argument
examples: The lawyer instanced several precedents to support her case
He instanced the recent policy changes as proof of progress

definitions: bring about or initiate an action or event deliberately
encourage or stir up undesirable or violent behavior in others
examples: She instigated a complete review of the company's policies
The committee instigated an investigation into the allegations
The troublemaker instigated a fight between the two groups
They were accused of instigating the riot

definitions: gradually but firmly establish an idea or attitude in someone's mind
put drops of liquid into something gradually
examples: Good teachers instill a love of learning in their students
Parents try to instill strong values in their children
The nurse will instill eye drops into the patient's eyes
Instill the medicine slowly to avoid discomfort

definitions: establish or set up an organization, system, or practice formally
begin or introduce a system, policy, or legal proceedings
examples: The university instituted a new scholarship program for minorities
They instituted strict safety protocols after the accident
The company instituted legal proceedings against the competitor
The government instituted reforms to improve healthcare access

definitions: teach someone a subject or skill through explanation and demonstration
tell or order someone to do something in a formal way
give a person legal directions or authorize them legally
examples: She instructs beginners in yoga every Monday evening
The professor instructed the class on proper laboratory techniques
The manager instructed all employees to attend the safety briefing
Please instruct the courier to leave packages at the door
The client instructed her lawyer to proceed with the lawsuit
The judge instructed the jury to disregard that testimony

definitions: arrange or write music for particular musical instruments
equip something with measuring or control instruments
examples: The composer will instrument the piece for a full orchestra
She instrumented the song for jazz quartet
Engineers instrumented the bridge to monitor stress levels
They instrumented the spacecraft with advanced sensors

definitions: protect something from heat, cold, or sound by surrounding it with material
protect someone or something from unpleasant influences or experiences
prevent electrical current from passing through by using non-conducting material
examples: We need to insulate the attic to reduce heating costs
They insulated the pipes to prevent them from freezing
His wealth insulated him from the harsh realities of poverty
The rural location insulated the community from urban problems
Electricians insulate wires with rubber or plastic coating
Always insulate electrical connections to prevent short circuits

definitions: speak to or treat someone with disrespect or scornful abuse
cause offense to someone's dignity or self-respect
examples: He insulted her intelligence by explaining simple concepts repeatedly
The customer insulted the waiter over a minor mistake
The low salary offer insulted his professional experience
Such behavior insults the memory of those who sacrificed

definitions: arrange for compensation in case of damage, loss, or death through insurance
make certain that something will happen or be the case
examples: We need to insure our new car against theft and damage
The company insures all employees for health and life coverage
Regular maintenance will insure the equipment operates efficiently
Double-checking insures accuracy in the final report

definitions: combine one thing with another so they become a whole
bring people or groups into equal participation in society
find the integral of a mathematical expression
examples: We need to integrate the new software with existing systems
The architect integrated modern elements with traditional design
The school works to integrate students from diverse backgrounds
The community integrated refugees through education programs
Students must integrate this function using substitution method
The mathematician integrated the complex equation

definitions: have something as one's purpose or objective when planning an action
design or mean something for a particular purpose or person
examples: I intend to finish the project before the deadline
She never intended to hurt anyone's feelings
This software is intended for professional graphic designers
The message was intended for the manager, not you

definitions: increase the degree, strength, or severity of something
become more intense, stronger, or more extreme
examples: The medication will intensify the treatment's effectiveness
They intensified security measures after the threat
The storm intensified as it moved toward the coast
Competition intensified between the two companies

definitions: place a dead body in a grave or tomb with ceremony
examples: They will inter his remains in the family cemetery
The soldiers were interred with full military honors

definitions: communicate or work together with others in a reciprocal way
act in such a way as to have a mutual effect on each other
examples: Students interact with teachers through online discussion forums
Children learn social skills by interacting with their peers
These chemicals interact dangerously when mixed together
The medications may interact and cause side effects

definitions: intervene on behalf of another person to help resolve a dispute
examples: The teacher interceded when the students began arguing
She interceded with the manager on her colleague's behalf

definitions: stop and seize someone or something in transit before reaching destination
mark or show where a line crosses a coordinate axis
examples: Security forces intercepted the suspicious package at the border
The defender intercepted the pass and scored a touchdown
The line intercepts the y-axis at point three
Calculate where the curve intercepts the x-axis

definitions: put each of two things in the other's place or position
exchange ideas, thoughts, or information between people
examples: You can interchange these two parts without affecting performance
The dancers interchange positions during the routine
The professors interchange ideas at the academic conference
The two cultures have interchanged traditions for centuries

definitions: connect with each other to form a network or system
examples: The subway lines interconnect at several major stations
These computer systems interconnect through fiber optic cables

definitions: prohibit or forbid something authoritatively especially in religious context
intercept and prevent the movement of enemy forces or supplies
examples: The church interdicted the practice of certain rituals
The court interdicted him from contacting the witnesses
Naval forces interdicted enemy supply ships
Air patrols interdict drug smuggling routes

definitions: arouse curiosity or attention and make someone want to know more
cause someone to undertake or acquire a financial share in something
examples: The unusual case interested detective more than routine investigations
Science documentaries interest students in complex topics
Can I interest you in investing in this startup?
The bank interested several clients in their new savings plan

definitions: intervene in a situation without invitation or necessity
prevent something from continuing or being carried out properly
combine waves to form a resultant wave pattern
examples: Please don't interfere with their personal decisions
The neighbor constantly interferes in our family matters
Bad weather interfered with our travel plans
The medication may interfere with your sleep patterns
Radio signals interfere when broadcast on similar frequencies
Light waves interfere to create colorful patterns

definitions: cross or weave things together by passing over and under alternately
examples: The artist interlaced gold threads through the fabric
She interlaced her fingers while waiting nervously

definitions: engage or connect together so movement of one part affects another
fit together tightly like pieces of a puzzle
examples: The gears interlock to transfer power through the mechanism
Safety systems interlock to prevent accidental activation
The puzzle pieces interlock perfectly along their edges
Their fingers interlocked as they held hands

definitions: provide or serve as a pause or break in activity or events
examples: Light music interluded between the dramatic scenes
Comic sketches interlude the serious presentations

definitions: act as an intermediary or go-between in a transaction
mediate or facilitate a process between parties
examples: The broker will intermediate between buyers and sellers
Banks intermediate financial transactions for their clients

definitions: work as a trainee to gain practical experience in a profession
confine someone as a prisoner especially for political or military reasons
examples: She will intern at the law firm during summer break
Medical students intern at hospitals before becoming doctors
The government interned suspected dissidents without trial
They were interned in camps during the war

definitions: explain the meaning of information, words, or actions
translate spoken words from one language to another immediately
perform a creative work in a way that conveys particular meaning
examples: Scholars interpret ancient texts to understand past cultures
How do you interpret the results of this experiment?
She interprets for diplomats at international conferences
Can you interpret what the speaker is saying?
The pianist interprets Chopin with remarkable sensitivity
Each actor interprets the role differently

definitions: question someone formally and thoroughly especially in aggressive manner
obtain data from a computer database through systematic queries
examples: Police interrogated the suspect for several hours
The committee will interrogate witnesses about the incident
The software interrogates the database every hour for updates
Engineers interrogate the system logs to find errors

definitions: stop the continuous progress of an activity or process
break into someone's speech or conversation
examples: The fire alarm interrupted the important board meeting
Don't interrupt your studies for minor distractions
She rudely interrupted while he was explaining the situation
Please don't interrupt when others are speaking

definitions: meet and cross at a point forming an angle or junction
have elements or interests in common that overlap
examples: The two roads intersect at the traffic light
These lines intersect at a ninety-degree angle
Our research interests intersect in several areas
Their lives intersected briefly during college

definitions: twist or twine together to form a single strand or unit
connect or link things closely so they affect each other
examples: The vines intertwine around the garden trellis
She intertwined ribbons to create a decorative braid
Their fates intertwined from that moment forward
Economic and political issues often intertwine

definitions: come between disputing people or groups to help resolve differences
take action to improve or change a situation or prevent something
examples: The mediator intervened to prevent the dispute from escalating
Parents sometimes need to intervene in children's conflicts
The government intervened to stabilize the failing economy
Doctors intervened quickly to save the patient's life

definitions: conduct a formal meeting to evaluate or question someone
participate as the subject of an interview
examples: The manager will interview three candidates this afternoon
Journalists interviewed witnesses at the scene
She interviewed well and got the job offer
He will interview for the position next week

definitions: hint or suggest something indirectly rather than stating it directly
state or make known something formally or officially
examples: She intimated that changes were coming without giving details
His expression intimated disapproval of the plan
The president intimated his decision to resign
They intimated their engagement at the party

definitions: frighten or threaten someone to make them do what one wants
make someone feel overawed or inadequate by impressive qualities
examples: The bully tried to intimidate younger students into giving him money
Witnesses were intimidated into remaining silent about the crime
The grand architecture intimidates visitors entering the courthouse
Don't let their expertise intimidate you from asking questions

definitions: arouse the curiosity or interest of someone through fascinating qualities
make secret plans to do something illicit or harmful
examples: The mysterious letter intrigued her for days
This scientific puzzle has intrigued researchers for decades
They intrigued against the government in secret meetings
Court advisors intrigued to gain more power

definitions: present someone formally to another person for the first time
bring something new into use or operation for the first time
insert or bring something into a place or situation
examples: Let me introduce you to our new marketing director
The host introduced the speaker to the audience
The company will introduce a revolutionary new product next month
Schools are introducing tablets into their classrooms
The doctor introduced a catheter into the patient's artery
Someone introduced poison into the water supply

definitions: enter a place or situation where one is unwelcome or uninvited
disturb someone's privacy or interfere without permission
examples: The photographer intruded into the celebrity's private property
Strangers intruded into the secure area
I don't mean to intrude on your personal time
Loud music intrudes on our peaceful evenings

definitions: understand or know something immediately through instinct without conscious reasoning
examples: She intuited that something was wrong before anyone said anything
Good teachers intuit when students are struggling
